content.description:
Three easy runout pitches to the right of SRI. Can be linked to SRI or Sanitarium may become better with traffic.

Trad

climbs.name: Delusional Reality
climbs.fa: p1-5 Michel Thibeault and Colin Dionne 1996, p6-12 Christie Lepitre and Colin Dionne 1999

content.description:
+) This route is an enjoyable outing involving 12 pitches of moderate cracks and slabs on the right-hand buttress of the formation Psyche Slab. As a party from Courtney discovered the hard way, bring two ropes! Rap the upper route to the terrace and locate a tree with slings. Rap three raps into the gully. Big Fun!

See the topo pic
Full trad rack

First pitch is the crux at about 10m up steep slabby corner. 5.10 finish.  The next pitch climbs out right under a beautiful undercling.  The last 2 pitches are all easier slab and bolted.

Starts in right facing corner 10m to the right of Racknophobia.
Full rack from rp's to yellow Camalot
If you you're not an absolute friction slab fanatic, this is what you should climb on your first day in the Eldred!
content.protection: 60m half ropes and gear to 3, double 1 and 2 and triples from .4 to .75

climbs.name: Psychopath
climbs.fa: Rob and Casey Richards, Lisa Padgett, and John hagen in 1988

content.description: This ten-pitch mega-classic is known for its traditional aesthetic appeal. It has no bolts, fixed anchors or other blemishes. Committing and often wet. Retreat requires leaving gear.

Bring some good rubber for this one. Climbs the wrinkle dikes formation on the frontal lobe. The first pitch is excellent and can be top-roped with a single 60meter cord. Joins Skits after three pitches and can be linked to the top of psyche slab with a very light rack. Shortens the rap from skits by two pitches.

Light rack

Michel Thibeault and Colin Dionne put up this ten pitch Trad slab route in 1995 to facilitate rapping off of Psyche slab. Ten full rope raps will get you to the ground after summiting. Scary.

Trad Rack

Check out the topo. Currently the hardest route on the slab.

In between delusional reality and Psychopath, check out the topo picture.
20 draws and slings. Set of nuts and a few RP's. 5 cams purple TCU to red camalot.

A modern classic with a ten-minute approach, Skits follows a stunning combination of steep slabs and discontinuous features.  Each of the routes twelve pitches is remarkable. Definitely a route that delivers, Skits is possibly the best apron route in western Canada. Fixed rap anchors allow easy descent.

https://vimeo.com/115652185
content.protection: Two 60m ropes and a full rack are necessary to supplement the ample bolts.

climbs.name: Seretonin Re-uptake Inhibitor (SRI)
climbs.fa: Brian Pickles, Luke Clark, Neil Ives 2005

content.description:
Climbs mixed ground to the left of Sanitarium. The first six pitches are lottsa fun, and most parties bail after six. This is the easiest route on Psyche Slab, and the first pitch is the crux. Rap the route.

Trad gear to supplement the cracks, areas without cracks are bolt protected. A bit run out on the second pitch.

Solstice provides a four-pitch, 5.10 alternative to the first six pitches of Schizophrenia. Rap Skits as pitch 2 of Solstice is a rope catcher.

Bring extra small gear.

Tachypsychia, 7 pitches, 5.6, 250m (a condition that distorts perception of time) This may be the Eldred’s first true moderate: a 7-pitch 5.6 actually made for the 5.6 climber. That’s not to say you don’t need to be competent and self-sufficient, but if easy well-protected trad is your jam, then this climb is for you. It’s also one of the only routes where you’ll find a shaded snack spot en route in the heat of the afternoon. Enjoy!  FAs: Marlaina Rhymer (MR), Braeden Ennis (BE), Alex Ryan Tucker (ART). Pitches 1-5 2018; Pitches 6-7 2019. Pitch 1: 5.4 (FA MR) Start in a shallow left-facing corner (running water after rain) to a small ledge. Continue up a straight-in broken crack to a tree belay on a cushy ledge.  Pitch 2: 5.6 (FA BE) Step out right onto the slab past 3 bolts to another shallow left facing corner. Continue up the corner as it turns into a straight-in broken crack. Gear belay.  *can link pitches 2 and 3 with careful rope drag management and a 70m rope Pitch 3: 5.4 (FA BE) Continue up the straight-in broken crack to a 2 bolt belay stance on the left.  Pitch 4: 5.6 (FA ART) Continue up crack to an overlap. Pull up over the overlap between a right facing corner and a bushy tree, and continue up the corner to a 2 bolt belay near a tree.  Pitch 5: 5.6 (FA BE) Continue up the right facing corner until it ends, then step right onto the slab towards a boulder and treed ledge with a 2 bolt belay.  Pitch 6: 5.6 “Roy Time 1” (FA MR) Step onto the slab above the belay, clip a bolt and continue to the crack out right. Follow this crack until another bolt leads you right onto the slab again, and onto another crack. Follow this crack to a small stance with a 2 bolt belay.  *can link pitches 6 and 7 with careful rope drag management and a 70m rope Pitch 7: 5.6 “Roy Time 2” (FA MR) Continue up the crack until another bolt leads you right onto the slab again, and onto a third crack and shallow left-facing corner. Follow this corner to another treed ledge and 2 bolt belay.  Descent: Rap the route as climbed with 2 x 60m ropes. Skip the gear belay and go direct from the top of Pitch 3 to the top of Pitch 1. As with most routes on the Psyche slab, you’ll be thankful for a pair of sandals on the rappel. Approach: take the trail left as for Day Pass / SRI. Before reaching SRI, look for blue flagging and a faint trail on the left. Follow the blue flagging through the forest, past a cool x-marks-the-spot boulder (you’ll know it when you see it), through a slide path, more forest, another slide path, and finally reaching the base at a large cedar. If you get lost in the forest, go back to the last piece of blue flagging and you should be able to see the next flag. If you get lost in the slide path, try to follow the path of least resistance. Long pants are recommended for bushwacking through the slide paths, at least until the approach sees some more traffic. Approach time: about 20 mins from the CAD Memorial Camp parking. Suggested rack: doubles to 2”, singles or doubles of 3” and 4”, 2 x 60m ropes for rappel. A 70m rope will allow you to link some pitches.

A chunk of Brazil right here in Beautiful British Columbia! A wonderful 380m (1245ft) of quintessential slabineering.

For the left side of the wall walk 5m up the road where a faint trail leads across the ditch on the right hand side of the road.

For the right side of the wall, walk 100m up the road to a trail just before the bridge across the b-branch creek.
